displayed_text: Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t have any bone pain. Don’t have any muscle pain per se. Uh. Doctor: So today we’re just going to go over stuff. And I, I mean it looks like unfortunately there’s been some changes that probably we’ll, we will have to call off the study. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Uh so the PSA to start with went up just a little, uh, so. Patient: It’s up around forty something isn’t it? Family Member: Six. Doctor: So it was forty-six, forty-three, forty-nine. So that’s almost the same number to me, maybe a little bit elevated from the last time. And then uh the bone scan we did looks pretty much the same. There’s really nothing new. Uh they’re seeing this bone spot they saw before, looks about the same. Uh they thought they saw a spot on the left side of your sternum. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Well that’s been there for- Doctor: Yeah. So that, that really, they don’t really see anything new. So the only thing that’s changed is you have a couple of lymph nodes in the abdomen, pelvis that are, got a little bit bigger. Patient: Oh they have gotten? Doctor: Yeah. So uh so they looked along the aorta which is the main focus for down the body.

Patient: Yes! I’ll take one. Doctor: You’ve got cancer, and I’m gonna treat ya. I’d like ya not to get the flu in the midst of therapy. Patient: Okay, then. Doctor: Because, then, it’s one thing I can cross off the list. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. We could do it today, or we could do it in a couple weeks when you’re gonna switch the Patient: Whichever’s easiest to - Family Member: Why don’t we get it out of the way? Patient: Thanks, dear. Family Member: Well. Family Member: What are these? Patient: One less thing to worry about. (pause)

Patient: So I all need to do now is go back to the lab and do… Doctor: No, no you’re probably gonna stay here and S__ will take you over because those are special tubes that she has to send out and all that. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: And would it be possible for me to have copies of that stuff? Doctor: Yeah I thought you might I know you usually want some. This is the bone scan. Patient: And my PSA wasn’t on the sheet. Do you guys have a number on that? Doctor: It’s not back. Did you do it yesterday? No today. Patient: We did labs today. Doctor: Oh, okay. No it’s not back yet then. I’ll take a look and let you know but Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it’s back. Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: so you’re fine. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So just wordsmithing, but enough for me Patient: Sure. Doctor: to make sure that we’re talking about this clearly. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So that there’s no misunderstanding. Patient: Sure, okay, okay. On the um on that biopsy result, Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: anything of any significance? Doctor: No I mean you have I think the P10 mutation which will be helpful for us because we have a study that actually targets that group of folks. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Not exactly what you want to do on vacation… Doctor: I know. That’s exactly right. I do it too. It needs to be done. I know. We all laugh at those. (Laughs) Family Member: It’s so hard. Doctor: I can think of a few closets of mine that I’ve been trying to ignore but then after a while it gets too much. (Laughs) Family Member: Oh I wish it was just closets. Doctor: Oh, it’s a lot more? Family Member: Oh yeah. Doctor: The garage I’m not evening tackling. Family Member: The basement. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah same thing. (Laughs) Family Member: Good luck. Doctor: Good luck is right. Patient: So I all need to do now is go back to the lab and do…

Patient: Yeah, mhm. Doctor: Well, um. I’m sorry that was the case. L-let’s talk about that. I wish I had known that a little earlier. But, the the reason that I’d like to talk about it is because it’s possible that we might need to make a switch in your treatment today anyway. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So um it is likely or or possible that I might be giving you a new prescription today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: For a different medication anyway. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um, we’ll have to see um what the PSA test looks like today. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But in the last few months it has been going up. Patient: I know it’s high today. Doctor: How do you know that?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Sound good? Patient: Thank you again. Doctor: Tell them before the end of July because I’m taking off June and July I’m having hip surgery. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So I’ll be seeing you though towards the end of July. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Did you want to see him before we go? Healthcare Professional: Yes I do.

Patient: Okay…
DOC Everything else will improve if you start to eat. I think he got that medicine that he gave me, your husband gave me… Doctor: Yep. Patient: I think it got some refills and I think I got about two more refills. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’ve been taking it though. Doctor: Perfect. Patient: Yep I’ve been taking it. Yep I have been taking it. Patient: Are you gonna give me the sixty OxyContin? Doctor: Yeah I gave you. One is sixty and then the Percocet is a… Patient: One hundred twenty? Doctor: One hundred twenty. Patient: Okay, last time you gave me OxyContin, you gave me one hundred twenty. Doctor: I know because that was the short acting. That’s what I’m telling you. The short acting OxyContin you had one hundred twenty. This is the long acting.

Patient: Okay. Alright. Family Member: If he has non-cancer issues, he goes to him primary? Patient: Primary doctor, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, they’re smarter than us. Family Member: If he thinks he has a hernia, would that show on the CT scan? Would that be appropriate to send to the doctor? Doctor: No, because, yeah, the hernia, you know, when you’re laying down it really has to be pretty bad for it to be seen laying down. It’s usually when you’re standing up or sitting that it comes out. A hernia just means you have a weak area of muscle and then you have your bowel spill out. Typically, it doesn’t bother you unless it gets stuck, you know. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having a lot of pain shooting up. Patient: Just I have a problem with my groin Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: a problem that we’re going out of town? Doctor: When are you going? Family Member: Saturday. Doctor: No. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: No. We won’t, I mean, with the holidays, you know, nothing happens. It’s almost like a, not a for sure. Next week it’s a shutdown, but a lot of places are still not functional- Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: -the first week of January.So, and, that’s, you know, reality is probably mid-January, I would imagine. Patient: Okay, well then… Doctor: Okay? Patient: We are leaving town on the… Family Member: The twelfth. Patient: The twelfth, and we’ll be gone for the twentieth. We’re going to Phoenix then.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. So, uh, if, so I guess the, the question is stay on this, this um, a clinic, stay in the clinical trial. Let’s see what happens the next, you know, three months from now. Doctor: Right. Patient: Is one option. And what other options are there? Doctor: Yeah. So, other options would be then we would stop this therapy and say that hey, you know, all the data says it’s gotten worse. Um, and, then we would look at other treatments. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: They’ve had Radium. You’ve got Abiraterone. You’ve got Enzalutamide. So, we would look at possibly chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, off, uh, clinical studies, chemotherapy would be, uh, the reasonable next step --- Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve got Taxotere, uh, would be what we would use. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: So, this is a prescription for Norco so theres, you know, it’s five slash three-twenty-five Patient: Okay. Doctor: so I think we provided one hundred twenty Patient: Right. Doctor: so we don’t want you to run out. Obviously, if you take all one hundred twenty at one time you’re in trouble so don’t do that. Patient: I would say, yeah I’m not gonna do that. Doctor: You take one or two at a time. Family Member: Call Monday and say we need more. Patient: Yeah, right. Yeah, this stuff’s really good. Doctor: The next thing you know the DEA is going H____ I hear you’re off this. No, not me. And I think here we have to, let me see, how do we get this from you? So, this is just a lot of the, sort of like a list and a contract if you will. Sort of these are all the risks, this is why we’re doing it. So, every time we prescribe opiates we have to do that now. Patient: I have to sign this? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s get M__ to just talk hard, here’s what gotta do, thinkin’ movin’ forward. Patient: Who is M_? Doctor: M_ S_!!!! You know M_! She’s the research nurse! You’ve talked to her a thousand times already! Patient: Ohhhh. Family Member: She come back every day. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: She nice. Doctor: she’ll kill ya! (Laughs) Patient: Okay. Okay. Family Member: She, she nice. Doctor: Yes, she’s very nice.

Patient: Hmm hmmm. Doctor: And the CAT scan. So that will be of your belly, your pelvis and your chest. Okay? Patient: Okay CAT scan is it’s not an MRI is it? Doctor: No. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Are you claustrophobic? Patient: Well no. (laughs) Doctor: And that was for your liver right? Patient: I guess so. Doctor: Yeah, So that’s different for your hepatitis. Patient: Now she says go down lower though. Doctor: Yes. So that side perfect. That will be helpful but not enough for us.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: I want to get – I not only want to get that but I would like to get one that does further and maybe practices in W____ … Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: …and operates out of the uh works out of the uh W____ location. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Makes it easier for us. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know your numbers always suggest that you’re dry. You know like you’re just a tad dehydrated. It always runs a little high. The other number we check is the B.U.N. or the bun. Patient: Right. Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: When you put those two together like a ratio, you’re a little dry so you need fluids. Patient: I, unfortunately, the last two days that’s been a little bit difficult because I was sitting in meetings. Doctor: Ahh. Okay. Patient: And driving so uh.
